title: Townsville dad-of-two, 36, dies of rare cancer
text:
A heartbroken wife has opened up about the heartbreaking moment she watched her husband take his last breath after 11 years battling a rare cancer with no cure.

Townsville father-of-two Michael Green, 36, died on October 2 after a long and hard fought battle with adenoid cystic carcinoma - a cancer that affects the salivary glands.

He has been remembered as a hard worker and loving family man dedicated to his wife Monique, and their two children Georgia, five, and Joseph, who turned three a week before his dad's death.

His wife posted a heart-wrenching Facebook tribute the day after Mr Green's death, along with photos of him in his hospital bed surrounded by his young family during his final days in palliative care.

Michael Green lost his cancer battle on October 2. He leaves behind a wife and two children

What is adenoid cystic carcinoma? Adenoid cystic carcinoma is a rare form of cancer that affects the salivary glands. It can also occur in the breast, uterus, or other locations in the body. Salivary gland tumors may cause painless masses in the mouth or face. Tumors of the may cause a bulging eye or changes in vision. Source: Rare Cancers Australia

'Yesterday my heart shattered into a million pieces when I watched my husband, best friend, soul mate and Georgia and Joseph's daddy take his last breath,' Mrs Green wrote.

'Words cannot describe the heart ache I'm suffering as my world has been torn apart.

'I miss him so much already and want him back in my arms, but one day that will happen.

'A massive thanks for all your love and support everyone has given us over the past few months. Mick was well loved by many now he is our guardian angel.'

Almost three weeks on, the young family are still grappling with the devastating loss.

Ms Green is trying to bring family life back to normal and will return to work as a nurse next week.

One of the last photos of Michael Green with wife Monique and children Georgia and Joseph

'Some days are better than others,' Ms Green told Daily Mail Australia.

'The morning and nights are the toughest when Mick was usually around, helping me with the kids. We're just taking each day as it comes at the moment.'

Mr Green was diagnosed with adenoid cystic carcinoma in 2008, two years before he met his wife on a night out in Townsville.

'He told the next day he had cancer which had no cure,' his wife recalled.

'The first thing that ran through my mind was that it would be difficult to have children and would have to go through IVF.

'Right from the start, I went to every doctor's appointment and check-up with him.'

'There was no backing away. The thought of walking away never crossed my mind. I knew there was something different about him.'

Monique met Michael two years after he was diagnosed with adenoid cystic carcinoma

She described her husband of six years as genuine, down to earth and a quiet man of few words.

'When we first met, making conversation with him was like pulling teeth but everyone said to me 'Oh, that's just Mick,' Ms Green laughed.

'He was loved by many people and would do anything for anyone.'

'He was my best friend and soul mate.'

Mr Green's health rapidly deteriorated in recent months and spent his final last four-and-a-half weeks in palliative care.

'We were told in June that he had another five years and three months later, he was gone,'Ms Green told Daily Mail Australia.

Michael (pictured with hs children) was genuine, down to earth and a quiet man of few words

'I went to see him on the Monday before he died and his eyes lit up when he saw me.

'I suggested we have a NRL grand final party the following Sunday in his room and he had the biggest smile on his face. He went downhill that afternoon and he died two days later.'

Mr Green took his health battle in his stride.

'He never let cancer get the better of him,' his wife said.

'He didn't want people to see him as Mick that had cancer.'

Ms Green has vowed to continue raising awareness about adenoid cystic carcinoma.

Monique found out about Michael's cancer the morning after they met at a Townsville nightclub in 2010. 'The thought of walking away never crossed my mind,' she said

The man known to his mates as 'Greeny' was also a passionate rugby league fanatic who won a A-grade premiership with his beloved Brothers Rugby League Club in 2010.

'Michael was a Brothers Junior whose contribution as a player and commitee member spanned over 20 years. He will be sadly missed,' the club posted following his death.

A GoFundMe page has been set up by friends Robert Peel and Kevin Toby Rowan to rally behind the young family Mr Green left behind, which has already raised more than $10,000.

The page describes Mr Green as 'an absolute legend and all-round top bloke.'

The tally will increase after a boxing night fundraiser is held this Saturday night.
description: Michael Green, 36, died on October 2 after being diagnosed with adenoid cystic carcinoma - a cancer that affects the salivary glands.
authors: Kelsey Wilkie For Daily Mail Australia
